questions.text: The most common organism causing osteomyelitis in drug abusers is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas

 

Option B)

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is most common organism in intravenous drug users and Salmonella is the most common organism in sickle cell anemia patients.
     

  • Extremity infections in Intravenous Drug Abusers (IVDA) can be due localised reaction at the injection site or due to haematogenous spread.
     

  • There have been an increase in the incidence of soft tissue abscess, osteomyelitis and septic arthritis presentations.

  • Initial literature suggested Pseudomonas species as the most common organism while Staphylococcus aureus was the most common organism three decades ago.
     

  • Most common organism overall – staph aureus
     

  • M/c in Genitourinary infection – E. coli
     

  • In neonates – heamophillus / group B streptococci

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In drug abusers, the most commonly found organism as the cause of osteomyelitis is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: Non-healing sinus is a common clinical feature is chronic osteomyelitis. The most common frequent cause for this presentation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of sequestrum

 

Option C)

 

  • Due to necrosis, pieces of dead bone separate as sequestra which are varying in size from spicule to large segment. It is lighter than live bone and normal pattern of bone is lost.

  • It acts as nidus and is most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis.

 

 

  • It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis.

  • Chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge can be seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Resistant organism. With wide utilization of antibiotics, mutation leads to resistant organism such as MRSA, VRSA. Such organisms are also causative agents for non-healing wound in case of chronic osteomyelitis.

 

Option B. Retained foreign body. Foreign body-induced osteomylitis – Since it is organic, it acts as a vulnerable medium for infections, hence retained wound foreign bodies may also result in fistula formation along with cellulitis or abscess formation as well as osteomyelitis and synovitis.

 

Option D. Intraosseous cavities. In chronic osteomyelitis, disruption of the intraosseous and periosteal blood supply leads to formation of a necrotic bone fragment. Such necrosis can form intraosseous cavities which cause non-healing sinus formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presence of the sequestrum is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Madura mycosis

 

Option B)

 

  • Madura mycosis (Mycetoma) is a chronic, progressively destructive infection of skin, subcutaneous tissue, fascia, and bone, often involving the foot. 
  • It is characterized by a "triad" of:
  • Swelling
  • Multiple discharging sinuses
  • Pus containing "grains" or "granules" (colonies of the causative organism)
  • Mycetoma can be caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma, caused by Actinomyces or Nocardia species). 
  • KOH smear would show filamentous structures (hyphae for eumycetoma, or branching filaments for actinomycetoma). 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteomyelitis: This is a bacterial infection of the bone. Presenting complaints are Fever (>38.3˚C), swelling of the limb, pain, systemic symptoms and increased levels of total leucocyte counts, ESR and CRP. Blood Culture is positive for staphylococcus aureus in 60% cases.

 

Option C. Anthrax: Anthrax is a bacterial infection (caused by Bacillus anthracis) that can manifest as cutaneous anthrax (a black eschar), inhalation anthrax, or gastrointestinal anthrax. This commonly presents with non-specific prodromal symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and sweats which progress to dyspnea and ultimately, respiratory failure and hemodynamic collapse. In cutaneous anthrax, the diagnosis is mostly clinical. However, confirmation can be established by the culture of the lesion, serologic testing, or punch biopsy. In inhalation anthrax, CT scanning of the chest is more sensitive. Sputum culture, gram stain, and blood cultures are not helpful in the acute phase. 

 

Option D. Actinomycosis: This is a chronic, suppurative (pus-forming) bacterial infection caused by Actinomyces species, which are filamentous bacteria. It frequently occurs at an oral, cervical or facial site, usually as a soft tissue swelling, abscess or mass that is often mistaken for neoplasm. Angle of jaw is most commonly involved. Involvement of bone is usually due to adjacent soft tissues. Mandible is most commonly involved. Vertebrae (spreading from lung or gut) or pelvis (spreading from cecum or colon) may also be involved. Infection of an extremity is uncommon. X-ray show cystic areas of bone destruction with concomitant bone formation and bone destruction. It is a type of actinomycetoma, which falls under the broader category of Mycetoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis. 
  • The filamentous structures observed on a KOH smear in Madura mycosis are hyphae which are the thread-like structures that make up the body of a fungus.
  • In Madura mycosis, the hyphae are typically thick-walledand septate (divided into compartments).
  • This presents as swelling of the extremity, pus discharge, and multiple sinuses.

Ans. A) Thenar space

 

Option A)

 

THENAR SPACE

 

  • It is lateral to lateral septum and must not be confused with the fascial compartment containing the thenar muscles.

  • It lies posterior to the long flexor tendons to the index finger and in front of the adductor pollicis muscle and contains the first lumbricals muscles.

 

 

Spaces of hand diagrammatic representation

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The infection from the index finger can spread to the thenar space of the hand.

choices.text: Most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: True about HIV-associated osteomyelitis is all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Necrosis absent

 

Option A) 

 

OSTEOMYELITIS IN AIDS

 

  • Osteomyelitis involves inflammation of bone and bone marrow, often leading to bone destruction and necrosis. 
  • HIV patients are more susceptible to conditions like avascular necrosis. 
  • In the bacterial osteomyelitis, bone necrosis is a hallmark.
  • Staphylococcus is the most common organism and often it is bilateral.
  • As pathophysiology of osteomyelitis is not altered, all the pathological changes seen in other osteomyelitis are seen in AIDS also.
  1. Dead necrotic bone (necrosis is present)
  2. Periosteal reaction (periosteal new bone formation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Often bilateral: While osteomyelitis can be multifocal or affect multiple bones in immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, but it is not always strictly bilateral. However, avascular necrosis, which is common in HIV patients, can indeed be bilateral. 

 

Option C. Periosteal new bone formation: Periosteal new bone formation (periosteal reaction) is a common radiological feature of osteomyelitis regardless of the patient's HIV status. The periosteum lays down new bone in response to inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. Most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus: Similar to the general population, Staphylococcus aureus remains the most common causative organism for bacterial osteomyelitis in individuals with HIV. While HIV patients can be susceptible to opportunistic infections, S. aureus is still the predominant pathogen for osteomyelitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In HIV-associated osteomyelitis, the most commonly found causative organism is the staphylococcus. 
  • The infection often presents bilaterally. 
  • The two commonly seen pathological features are necrosis of the bone and periosteal new bone formation.

questions.text: Most common organism for Postsurgical osteomyelitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus

 

Option A)

 

  • Commonest causative organism for Post-traumatic osteomyelitis/Post-surgical osteomyelitis - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Bacterial biofilms attached to orthopedic devices implanted during the operation can increase the rate of postoperative osteomyelitis infection.
  • Open fractures are potentially more prone to the development of postoperative osteomyelitis infection because of the direct intrusion of foreign bacterial flora.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas. This organism causes multifocal and recurrent osteomyelitis, and septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Streptococcus. β-hemolytic streptococci is responsible for causing post-streptococcal reactive arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common organism for post-surgical osteomyelitis is staphylococcus aureus.

choices.text: ESR and white blood cell counts are usually normal
Ultrasound of the joint reveals widening of the joint space
The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

questions.text: Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) of the hip is characterized by all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

 

Option D)

 

TRANSIENT (TOXIC) SYNOVITIS OF HIP

 

  • It is self-limiting, inflammatory condition of synovium.
  • It is the common cause of hip pain and limping in children of 6 to 12 years of age.
  • Boys are affected 2-3 times more than girls.
  • 95% cases are unilateral.
  • A recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection of viral origin is usually present.
  • The joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation because in this position, the joint capacity is maximum (so stretching due to effusion is minimal), thus causing least pain.
  • Physical examination is characterized by guarded rotation of hip joint.
  • Pain can be elicited at the extreme of motion.
  • The patient is non-toxic and rarely have temperature above 38˚C or any indications of systemic illness.
  • The white blood cells (WBC) count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Radiographs are normal or have slightly widened joint space medially.
  • Ultrasound reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveals a WBC count between 5,000 and 15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The transient synovitis of the hip is usually a manifestation after an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • On physical examination, the hip joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation position (FABER).
  • ESR and WBC levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Ultrasound investigation of the hip reveals mild effusion and widened joint space.

questions.text: Osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salmonella

 

Option A)

 

  • Patients with sickle cell anemia have a unique susceptibility to certain infections, including osteomyelitis due to several factors like functional asplenia and areas of bone infarction, which create an environment conducive to bacterial growth. 
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, in individuals with sickle cell disease, Salmonella species are disproportionately common.
  • The vaso-occlusive crises characteristic of sickle cell disease can lead to micro-infarctions in the bone marrow. 
  • These areas of ischemic and necrotic bone can serve as a nidus for bacterial infection, particularly by gut-derived organisms like Salmonella.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Streptococcus: Streptococcus is the common causative organism in patients with osteomyelitis normally. 

 

Option C. Haemophilus: This organism is responsible for septic arthritis. 

 

Option D. Neisseria: This also causes septic arthritis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease is caused due to salmonella infection. 
  • Different etiologies for osteomyelitis are:

Ans. B) Hip joint of infants

 

Option B)

 

TOM SMITH ARTHRITIS

 

  • Tom Smith Arthritis is septic arthritis of hip in infants which may destroy the cartilaginous femoral head rapidly and completely (chondrolysis).
  • So, child presents with limp, unstable gait, shortening of limb, telescopy and increased hip movements in all direction.
  • Treatment includes procedures to stabilize the hip.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neck of infants. Septic arthritis of cervical spine is rarely seen in infants.

 

Option C. Elbow joint in children. Septic arthritis of the elbow in children is a rare.

 

Option D. Shoulder joint in children. Septic arthritis of the glenohumeral joint in the pediatric population (<18 yo) is not commonly seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tom Smith arthritis most commonly affects the hip joint of the children.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male came with swelling of upper end tibia which is surrounded by a rim of reactive bone. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brodie’s Abscess

 

Option B)

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • Seen in Immunocompetent Host.
  • It is long-standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long-standing because of strong defence mechanism of body).
  • This is a localized form of subacute or chronic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis), e.g. Upper end tibia.
  • It is classically described as an oval or round lytic (radiolucent) lesion in the metaphysis of a long bone, surrounded by a thick, dense rim of reactive sclerosis (reactive bone).

 

 

  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.
  • It often presents with localized pain and swelling.
  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative).
  • Brodie's abscess is common in children and adolescents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Giant cell tumor (GCT): Radiologically, the GCT appears as eccentrically located, subchondral, radiolucent lesions in the epiphysis of the long bones, with well-defined non-sclerotic margins. GCTs typically occur in skeletally mature individuals (20-40 years old) and are usually epiphyseal lesions (though they can extend to the metaphysis). While they are lytic, they generally lack a prominent rim of reactive sclerosis. They are uncommon in a 12-year-old.

 

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis. There is generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, presence of brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull. It is a metabolic bone disorder, not typically presenting as a localized lesion with a reactive rim in a child after a single injury. 

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: Acute osteomyelitis typically presents with more diffuse lytic changes, soft tissue swelling, and periosteal reaction, but not necessarily a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by a thick reactive rim. Chronic osteomyelitis can have sequestrum and involucrum, but the specific description of a well-circumscribed lesion with a reactive rim strongly points to Brodie's abscess. Acute osteomyelitis usually presents with more acute symptoms (fever, severe pain) and initially, on X-ray, might show subtle changes like soft tissue swelling or periosteal reaction. Chronic osteomyelitis can involve reactive bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Swelling of upper end tibia seen to be surrounded by a rim of reactive bone radiologically is suggestive of the diagnosis of Brodie’s abscess.
  • Age of 12 years in this case is a critical piece of information. Certain bone pathologies are more prevalent in specific age groups.
  • The upper end of the tibia (proximal tibia) is a common site for various bone lesions, particularly in children, often involving the metaphysis or epiphysis.
  • Radiological feature of "surrounded by a rim of reactive bone" is the most distinctive clue. A rim of reactive bone, or sclerosis, suggests a chronic, well-localized, or walled-off process where the body has had time to react and contain the lesion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chronic osteomyelitis

 

Option B)

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • It is usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • The causative organism is staphylococcus aureus.

 

1. Sequestrum:

 

  • Avascular piece of bone surrounded by granulation tissue, it is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis.
    • It acts as nidus of infection and is most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis.
    • Chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge can be seen.

 

2. Involucrum is dense sclerotic new bone surrounding the sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum (usually obvious by the end of 2nd week).

 

  • At least 2/3rd surface of sequestrum should be surrounded by involucrum before carrying out sequestrectomy (Removal of Sequestrum).

 

3. If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge through perforations in involucrum (cloacae).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients with Ewing sarcoma. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling, suggesting osteomyelitis. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma.  Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis; however, only about 25% of patients experience this phenomenon. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture tibia. a common complaint is pain with activity which subsides with rest. Pain gradually worsens over time when continuing the aggravating activity. Swelling and tenderness may also be present around the area of pain. Initial radiographs are normal early in the course of a stress fracture. They appear to be positive once healing begins to occur (specific but not sensitive). Even after healing has begun to occur, radiographic findings can be subtle and may be easily overlooked.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given radiographic image in the question and the patient’s symptoms is suggestive of presence of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Paprika sign during debridement is crucial in management of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic osteomyelitis

 

Option A) Chronic Osteomyelitis

 

  • Paprika sign is seen during the surgical debridement of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Paprika sign is appearance of live bone after removal of sequestrum.

 

 

Paprika Sign

 

  • The limits of debridement have classically been determined by the “Paprika sign” which is characterized by punctuate cortical or cancellous bleeding.
  • Reactive new bone surrounding an area of chronic infection is living and usually does not require debridement. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma.  Osteosarcoma is a malignant osseous neoplasm. It is the most common primary bone cancer of childhood. Treatment for osteosarcoma is mainly wide local excision along with chemotherapy. Radiotherapy rarely is utilized.

 

Option C. Osteoid osteoma.  An osteoid osteoma is a benign bone-forming tumor that has no potential to become malignant. It classically causes severe pain at night relieved with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications.

 

Option D. Brodie’s abscess.  Brodie abscess is one type of subacute osteomyelitis. It is difficult to diagnose. Treatment includes debridement and drainage of pus. Paprika sign is seen. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Paprika sign is seen during the debridement of chronic osteomyelitis which indicates the presence of a live bone after the removal of the sequestrum.
  • Paprika sign also helps is defining extend of debridement required for healthy tissue.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male complains of fever and pain right hip. On examination, he has swelling in right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip and there is mild reduction in movements in right hip region. On X-ray, there is mild increase in medial joint space. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transient synovitis 

 

Option B)

 

TRANSIENT SYNOVITIS

 

  • Transient synovitis is a self-limiting inflammatory condition of synovium.
  • It is a common cause of hip pain and limping in children aged 6-12 years of age.
  • It is also known as irritable hip, observation hip, coxitis serosa and coxalgia fugax.
  • Boys are affected 2–3 times more than girls.
  • 95% cases are unilateral, right and left hips are affected equally.
  • A recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection of viral origin is usually present.
  • The joint is held in Flexion, abduction and external rotation because in this position the joint capacity is maximum (so stretching due to effusion is minimal), thus causing least pain.
  • Physical examination is characterized by guarded rotation of hip joint.
  • Pain can be elicited at the extreme of motion.
  • The patient is non-toxic and rarely have temperature above 38˚C or indications of systemic illness.
  • The WBC count, CRP level, and ESR usually are within normal limits.
  • Radiographs are normal or have slightly widened joint space medially.

 

 

  • Ultrasound reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveals a WBC count between 5,000-15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Septic arthritis. Clinically, in septic arthritis, the hip remains in the position of flexion, abduction and external rotation as this is the position of maximum capacity of joint to accommodate pus. X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swellings. MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction and aspiration of joint will help to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and can also help to differentiate from transient synovitis.

  • Septic arthritis with negative cultures – Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and associates criterion) - 5 out of 6 must be present
    1. > 38.3°C temperature
    2. Swelling of joint
    3. Pain in joint that increases with movement
    4. Systemic symptoms
    5. No other pathologic process
    6. Satisfactory response to antibiotics therapy
  • Difference between Septic Arthritis and Transient Synovitis (Both have flexion abduction and external rotation at hip):

 

 

Option C. Tubercular hip. Tuberculous arthritis is a rare finding in children. Usually monarticular, it involves primarily the weight-bearing joints and only exceptionally the joints of the upper extremities. Most patients presenting with tuberculous arthritis will present with indolent joint swelling due to synovial hypertrophy. There is warmth and redness accompanying the swelling. Radiologically, there is peri-articular osteoporosis, peripherally located osseous erosion and gradual joint space narrowing.

 

 

Option D. Dislocation of hip. Hip dislocation in children is rare. It is generally a result of significant trauma. The key to clinical diagnosis is the abnormal position of the limb, with the inability to move the hip.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given history of the patient of fever and pain right hip; swelling in right hip region; flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip; and mild reduction of movements in right hip region; with mild increase in medial joint space on x-ray are suggestive of transient synovitis of the hip.
  • This is so because, the patient is 7 years old, which is the peak age for transient synovitis.
  • Fever, pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the hip are common symptoms of transient synovitis.
  • A mild increase in medial joint space is often seen in transient synovitis, indicating inflammation in the joint.

questions.text: X-ray shoulder of the patient with following image shows:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

Option D)

 

  • Observe the sequestrum surrounded by less dense granulation tissue and new bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma.  Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma.  Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given X-ray image shows sequestrum in the centre surrounded by the involucrum and deformed bone in the chronic osteomyelitis of the upper end of the humerus.

questions.text: A boy presented with multiple non-suppurative osteomyelitis with sickle cell anemia. What will be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salmonella

 

Option A)

 

MULTIFOCAL OSTEOMYELITIS: They are two varieties in which this topic can be asked:

 

  1. Chronic Recurrent Multifocal Osteomyelitis (CRMO) is an autoimmune/auto inflammatory disease involving multiple bone with lesions, inflammation and pain. There is no infection. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Some relate it to SAPHO syndrome.
    • SAPHO Syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Palmo-plantar pustulosis, Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
    • Treatment is NSAIDs/Steroids/Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drugs (DMARD).
  2. Sickle cell Anemia can involve multiple bones, hence it can cause multifocal osteomyelitis and causative organism is Salmonella.
    • In acute cases, the patient with sickle cell anemia and osteomyelitis presents with fever, painful and swollen limb with limited range of motion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S. aureus. In the general population, Staphylococcus aureus (S aureus) is the most common organism associated with osteomyelitis. In sickle cell disease, Salmonella spp. is more commonly found.

 

Option C. H. influenzae. The most common infections caused by H.influenzae are pneumonia, meningitis, cellulitis, infectious arthritis etc.

 

Option D. Enterobacter species. They less commonly cause soft tissue infections and osteomyelitis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Multiple, non-suppurative osteomyelitis with sickle cell anemia is most commonly caused by salmonella species.

questions.text: Septic arthritis in a 2-year-old child is often caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option B) 

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis in all ages.
  • Typical pathogens for septic arthritis in different pediatric age groups:
    • Neonates (0-1 month): Group B Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, and Gram-negative bacilli (e.g., E. coli) are common.
    • Infants and Young Children (1 month to ~3-5 years):
      • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause across all pediatric age groups, including this one.
      • Kingella kingae has emerged as an important cause in children under 2-3 years, often being a more subtle or less acutely severe infection.
      • Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was a significant cause historically, but its incidence has dramatically reduced in vaccinated populations due to the Hib vaccine. However, non-typeable H. influenzae or other serotypes can still cause infections, though less commonly.
  • Older Children and Adolescents: Staphylococcus aureus remains prevalent. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) can also be seen. Neisseria gonorrhoeae should be considered in sexually active adolescents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: The most common infections caused by H.influenzae are pneumonia, meningitis, cellulitis, infectious arthritis etc.

 

Option C. Gonococci: Gonococcal Arthritis in toddlers is a rare occurrence. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The causative organism of septic arthritis in a 2-year-old child is often the staphylococcus aureus. 
  • Haemophilus influenzae was historically relevant, but widespread vaccination has reduced its prevalence significantly. 
  • Gonococcal arthritis is associated with sexual activity or perinatal transmission, neither of which is typical for a 2-year-old. 
  • Pneumococci can cause septic arthritis but are far less common than Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: Deformity seen in transient synovitis of hip is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

  • Hip position is flexion, abduction and external rotation as this is the position of maximum capacity of joint to accommodate pus.
  • The stretching due to effusion is minimal in this position of the hip, thus there is least pain in this position.
  • FABER is seen in:
    • Transient synovitis
    • Septic arthritis
    • 1st Stage of TB Hip
    • Anterior dislocation of hip
    • Iliotibial band contracture

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In transient synovitis of the hip, the deformity of the hip seen is flexion, abduction and external rotation i.e., FABER.

choices.text: Affects pulp space of finger
Staphylococcus is the causative organism
Transverse incision is usually used
All septae should be broken

questions.text: True about felon are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transverse incision is usually used

 

Option C)

 

FELON

 

  • A felon is an abscess in the subcutaneous tissues of distal pulp of most commonly thumb > index finger.
  • The distal digital pulp is divided into tiny compartments by strong fibrous septa that traverse it from skin to bone.
  • A transverse fibrous curtain also is present at the distal flexor finger crease.
  • S. aureus is the organism most commonly isolated from fingertip infections.
  • Swelling, redness, and pain, typical of cellulitis, initially are present.
  • Abscess formation may follow rapidly.
  • Treatment consists of antibiotics and longitudinal incision for drainage.
  • Complications are Osteomyelitis > Tenosynovitis

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A felon is an abscess that affects the distal pulp space of the finger.
  • Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism.
  • During its treatment, a longitudinal incision is usually made and all the fibrous septae should be broken to prevent infection spread from the skin to the bone.

questions.text: Infection of ulnar bursa is diagnosed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kanavel's sign

 

Option A)

 

KANAVEL’S SIGN

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chvostek’s sign. The Chvostek sign is a clinical finding associated with hypocalcemia. This clinical sign refers to a twitch of the facial muscles that occurs when gently tapping an individual's cheek, in front of the ear. The Chvostek sign aims to elicit an atypical reaction of the facial nerve. The pressure caused by the tapping acts as a triggering stimulus for involuntary contractions of the facial muscles ipsilaterally. The sign is considered negative when no contractions of the facial muscles occur after stimulation of the facial nerve.

 

 

Option C. Gower’s sign. Gowers sign is the characteristic patterns observed in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy wherein they 'climb up' their thighs with the aid of their hands to overcome the weakness of their pelvic and proximal lower limb muscles. 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Infection of the ulnar bursa (suppurative tenosynovitis) is diagnosed by the Kanavel’s sign.
  • The 4 cardinal features of the Kanavel’s sign are:
    1. Tenderness over the involved sheath
    2. Rigid finger flexion position
    3. Pain on finger hyperextension
    4. Swelling of the involved part
